reviewText:
The Banner Saga has stunning landscape art, a great soundtrack, a compelling story and indeed would make a fine visual novel (provided you don't mind 80's cartoon style character art). Actually, if it were several dollars less (or on sale) it would be worth recommending on that merit. Unfortunately, they have made the mistake of attempting to pack a game in with this work of art and underlying game is really bad.

Barring some scant and predictable events, you have no control and no agency in the traveling portion of the game. Strategy essentially amounts to buying enough food at each stop to last out a journey of predictable length. The game even makes a lame attempt to reference Oregon Trail at one point but you can't alter your pace, hunt for food or any of that. All you can do is watch the caravan move and occasionally click a pop-up. While the timing of the events can be random, the results of the choices are predictable and usually so inconsequential overall they are essentiall cosmetic.

Much of the criticsm of the battle system revolves around the choices made for its turn-based system. While the system is valid, no effort has been made for the AI to take advantage of it. The opposing force scripting is simplistic in fact, that it is outright self-destructive with some units because simple checks were not put in place for splash damage abilities. The battles take place at scripted intervals with scripted rosters and all but one of the battle maps are simple rectangular grids.

Conclusion: Wait for a sale, turn the difficulty to Easy. Bear with the game and enjoy the art and story.

reviewText:
This game is not a sandbox storytelling game like King of Dragon Pass or Crusader Kings II. It's far too linear for that, even though you can somewhat influence where the story branches at certain points. Don't expect too much control over things.

This game isn't that much of a turn-based tactics battler. Sure, the combat is okayish and gives you something to do in addition to clicking through dialogue, but I never found the fights that engaging and at times it was dull and repetitive. There are way more interesting turn-based combat games out there, don't grab this if that's what you're looking for.

However, this game is a pretty good visual novel! The story and characters were interesting, the world is mysterious and the art and music side is well done. If you want to experience a pretty gripping viking fantasy survival story, this game works. Well, at least until the end, when there's not enough closure and it becomes pretty obvious that this is actually The Banner Saga: Episode 1 and it's definitely building up to a sequel. At least the game doesn't over-explain things so the sense of mystery remains.

Still, if you enjoy nice hand-painted visuals and very light RPG story elements and just want to be told a neat story, this is a decent experience for that. Just don't expect any sprawling larger-than-life epic, this is quite quickly over even though the world and lore probably could support a larger game in the same setting.

reviewText:
As a person who likes turn based strats HoMM, Disciples, KingsBounty I had high hopes for this game. After finishing it for the most part on normal difficulty I want to but I really cant reccomend people buying it.

The good : Amazing visuals, animation and sountrack. Thats about it.

The bad: it would be easy to say everything else but im going to elaborate.

With such an amazing score and visuals the game has virtually no voicework to accompany the dialogues. Which would ok if it werent for hte fact that they are either poorly translated or just badly written. You can skip 90% of the dialogue and still be on the same page if you had been paying attention.

The unitally cool and challenging combat quickly becomes boring or unfair depnding in you difficulty level. There arent many different enemies so you end fighting the same 4-5 guys for 9 hours and the strategy never evolves beyond gang up on the weak guy. The special abilities of each hero are very situational and I maybe used 3 abilities regulary.

Some mechanics are downright broken. The demand for provisions to supply the caravan is completely optional since there virtually no penatly to loosing clansmen/varl. The renown points (with which the game is very stingy) are better spent on your crew and gear.  Beware some party memebers are prone to sudden death during the random encours on the road. So dont be surpised if a badass warhawk level 5 gets killed by dregeling off screen with little infleunce by the player.

Despite the strong visual and audio presentation the story is moot and the characters never evolve beyond thier booring achetypes. The pampered prince, the innocent girl, the reluctant leader etc.

Over all I would say stay away from this beatiful siren fo a game no matter how tempting the and song lull you to its purchase

reviewText:
[+] Interesting blend of convoy management, adventure game dialogue choices & turn-based tactical combat

[-] 2D art style prevents rotation of scene, often resulting in smaller units and enemy traps being obfuscated
[-] Convoy management meta-game seemed pointless
[-] Lack of quality-of-life features such as inventory management before battles & enemy team movement/combat range during combat
[-] Frustrating difficulty spike in final battle that resulted me lowering the difficulty to complete the game

Despite what seems like a mixed bag, the game, which I bought initially to support Stoic's stance against King.com, hooked me in for hours of fun. I'm still looking forward to the next part of the Banner Saga.

reviewText:
Be aware that you are going to play this game for about 8 hours and absolutely love it, and then you'll be left dumbfounded by the direction it suddenly takes.

As I said, you'll love it; that is if you like the idea of a role-playing turn-based strategy game in which almost every character has their own unique abilities, and thus worth to a battle. Characters level up like in typical RPGs and you can equip them with stat-enhancing gear (only one though, and the highest level is 5). You'll quickly decide your front 6 and rarely deviate from it.

You will also learn that this game outright hates you, dealing you pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cards when you are called upon to make a decision. Not always ♥♥♥♥♥♥, however - some lead almost nowhere. But this where the story is primarily told, and because of these infrequent horrible decisions, and the occasional story-affecting choices, the saga feels like it's yours. I'm quite confident that someone out there has done precisely the same things as I did in this game, but, whilst I was playing it, it didn't feel that way.

The art style is pretty. Think 50's-80's Disney style stationary art with basic movements programmed in for battles, but with the minimal, yet highly appreciated, foreground and background falling snow to give it an easy 3D effect. Nice all around.

My only beef with this game is it's story, particularly the ending. It just ends to soon to put it plainly. Any self-respecting storywriter (who knows or does not know that they may be writing a trilogy) would not have ended it in this way. So many great and interesting angles are left unexplored and hardly explained! The Gods are dead (not much of a spoiler as it's right at the beginning of the game) and yet no explanation is offered. The sun has stopped moving (again, beginning) and no explanation is offered. The (apparent) main boss is introduced 2/3 of the way through without any previous hinting of how significant he's going to be. Why? Because his significance is paired with his existence. Very poor. And it's not even like he's a good main boss: there is a literal earth-shatterer that would have made for a killer main boss!

The storywriters need firing for this one. Actually, just fire the ones who argued that it should end in this way because they need to go back to junior school. I don't care if a trilogy had been in the plan the whole time, a good story does not introduce a key aspect of the storyline and then just do nothing with it.

I do recommend this though. It's a great game. The tone is excellent and it really feels like your saga. When you finish in a day (if your dedicated enough) you'll see what I mean by just how ♥♥♥♥ing disgraceful the ending is.

reviewText: Check out our full review at VGBlogger.com: http://www.vgblogger.com/discussion-review-the-banner-saga/25152/\n\nParts of The Banner Saga feel incomplete or less fleshed out than they could have been, and in some cases outright and purposefully unforgiving in order to match the storyline's harsh tone and subject matter. But taken as a whole the experience is deeply fulfilling, thanks to well developed characters that you will actually care about and want to get to know, a narrative and game world of epic scope, and a tactically rich turn-based battle system that puts some smart twists on tradition. And what more can I say about the game's stunning artistry? Some of the cutscene portraits and landscape shots made me wish I could print them out and frame to hang on my wall, instead of only being able to capture them as screenshots to use for desktop wallpapers. If Disney or Rankin/Bass ever made a mature cel-animated movie about Vikings, it would probably look a whole lot like The Banner Saga.

reviewText:
A good game with excellent art and style but a basic combat system. Nice to hear the authentic accents in the few spoken lines and the music is outstanding. The gameplay consists of dialogue choices and a basic turn-based, grid combat system. As with all the best choice based dialogue games, some of the choices are the sort that cause you to sit and think for 30 minutes before selecting something you immediately regret.

The combat is repetitive and once I had a go-to team I found it difficult to break from a routine (giants at the front to smash some up the baddies, archers at the back to pick off the smashed). The combat almost feels like it was added to make the game a game instead of what could have been an excellent interactive story. It beats quick time events I guess but the lack of enemy types makes everything too easy. When got bored of the combat I bumped the Difficulty setting down to Easy only to find out it was the final battle in the game. So, it was good enough for my 10 hour play time.

Everything about the game feels very much like a touch screen was always in the back of the developers minds. This is not a complaint, the play style is perfected suited for dropping in and out to extend what can be a pretty bleak story. The odds are certainly against all of the characters and a string of badly handled choices can result in some miserable  setbacks.

I picked the game up in the Summer sale 2014, excellent value for money. I'm on board for the planned sequels. More spoken dialogue and improved combat would build on the excellent foundation set up with The Banner Saga.

reviewText:
Banner Saga is a study in videogames as a storytelling medium. The score, the sounds, the visual style, and the writing all work together beautifully to tell the story of a merciless world falling apart. It's tense and you're always on the verge of annihilation, and the music alone could tell you so. It's gritty, and the crunches of axes breaking armor and the grunts and moans of the injured make you feel it. People are fragile and the perpetual march is exhausting, and the heavy shambling motions of bodies shows you so.  As the leader, you constantly have to arbitrate the problems of your followers, keep them optimistic, keep them fed, and keep them alive while a continent of panicking and desperate people is being overrun.  Everything harmoniously comes together to weave an atmosphere where feelings of dread and anxiety are constant. Your choice isn't whether or not people die, it's who dies now so that fewer will die later.  In every artistic regard this game is an achievement.

Unfortunately it's not for everyone, though. Its roots are in the artistry, not the gameplay--people have some valid complaints about that. Only some. I didn't dislike the gameplay at all, but I was very wrapped up in every other part of the game.

Play it for the experience.

reviewText:
God we need more games like this one!

The Banner Saga is the first part of an ambitions adventure game created by indie developers. The gameplay is quite simple but entertaining and enhanced with 3 levels of difficulty. The level design is gorgeous, it's deeply inspired by the art of Eyvind Earle but it still has it's own identity. Anyway it's the story that makes this game different from other RPG/Adventure games.

First, the world is a perfect mixture between nordic mythology, fantasy and apocalyptic fiction. The story is about survival and beliefs, in this chaotic snowy and cold landscape three races try to escape the forthcoming shadows. This first part is centered on the story of Rook, a hunter, who try desperately to save his kin and his traveling companions from starvation, killing each other and from the dredge's return. The story really evolves depending of your choices, you can build strong relations with some characters and at the same time don't even meet the other ones. You can easily loose your best mates after making a mistake that seemed to be the good thing to do at the time. It makes the story really moving, mature and immersive. And personally that's why I play video games, not to kill dozens of monsters but to feel something.

I'm waiting for the second part with great excitement and you should do the same !

reviewText:
Turn-based combat RPG with interesting story, decision-making and combat system.

The art is very crisp. Sound is good too.

The combat system involves armor and health/strength. Losing health diminishes the strength of a character, and losing armor means they are more vulnerable. If strength is too low itll be hard to attack an enemy with higher armor level. First time Ive seen such a system in a game and it makes for more thoughtful and careful play. As I began figuring out the system my enjoyment of combat increased a lot as I began to make the right decisions and win more battles. For example, archers arent very strong against armored enemy, but they can plink away at armor whilst the melee character moves in - once both have broken they can both finish off the enemy quick.

Also theres a practice battle option which provides random set of enemies. It doesnt improve or injure your heroes, just practice. These are usually harder than what you face in the normal game, allowing you to improve a lot and learn how to beat the odds. Playing on the hardest difficulty is essential I think otherwise you might find it too easy. If you like the game's combat is a good addition and adds a bit more to the game's challenge. You can also change how many heroes you go into the battles with so that can make it more of a challenge and make you a better player.

The game doesn't demand much from your PC/Mac but stills delivers a very nice gameplay, artstyle and music.

Its pretty hardcore in that you can't do manual saves (just auto-saves) and thus forces you to live with the decisions you've made. If you want to undo a decision you made, you have to go back to the last auto-save which sometimes might involve fighting certain battles again to rereach the point when the decision was made.

All in all, I really enjoy playing this game. If you're a fan of turn-based startegy games like FF Tactics with added decision making, this game is highly recommended.

reviewText: The game is simply fabulous. A rare mix of a tactical combat with equal dose of text adventuring, where both parts are most interesting by themselves and manyfold so due to their interaction. Tactical combat is an exquisite work of visual gaming art by itself, a rare case when out of elegance of simplicity a stunning complexity of battle is wrought. Adventuring part is equally a first-rate experience, where the most innocent (or well-intentioned) decision may lead to disastrous consequences, and sometimes vice-versa. And, last not least, all of it set with lovingly (and as for me, also breathtakingly) made CG.\n\nAlso, it is very reminiscing of a much older game with many similar moments (including somewhat similar nordic setting) - King of Dragon Pass[en.wikipedia.org], which I recommend to anyone who liked Banner Saga.

reviewText:
Raise your banners it's the saga... The Banner Saga.
This game... There aren't a lot of fantasy settings that really get me, but this one was one of the few. It's a kind of desolate, nordic setting with some focus on a few political aspects. Love it.

The game has a special art style which wasn't really my thing, but nevertheless very thorough and unique, it has a strong focus on story, but not in your typical fashion, and has a strategic HOMM/XCOM-like battle system with RPG features, like individual character levels, skills and Items.

If you want about 8-12 hours of story-driven gameplay with a pretty good but not amazing combat system, this is a really good choice and the release price wasn't extremely expensive. My biggest complaints are the length and that I want a sequel to delve further into this fantasy world.

reviewText:
Amazing game. It's like a cross between a turn-based tactical RPG like Final Fantasy Tactics or Shining Force, and King of the Dragon Pass. Basically, there's quite a bit of combat (which would be the FF Tactics bit), but between them you have a ton of story-based and random events that requite you to make a ton of (at times really, really tough) choices. The actual story is very good, although it's rather bleak (which is a perfect fit for the Viking setting, of course).

Add to that a suberb art design, composed of breathtaking traditional 2D art like I've never seen before in a computer game; and a fantastic soundtrack, and you've got yourself a truly amazing game. It's not flawless, though: while some of those flaws (like lack of full voice acting) are completely understandable, given Stoic's small size, others (like the lack of subtitles, or being forced to replay the last five hours of gameplay due to some decision you took waaaay back that now means game over for you) are not.

But even with these flaws the game is still a gem, totally worth the two years Stoic took to develop it since the game's Kickstarter campaign was funded in 2012.

Need refund! I thought this was the hit match 3 game with a candy theme. Too much confusion...

But in all seriousness, The Banner Saga is an excellent game that no strategy fan should overlook. It tells a compelling story both on a grand scale and at a personal level.

reviewText:
This game is immaculate, from the artwork and gameplay, to the way you manage supplies and your clans happiness during travels.  Every decision you make in the game is important and a lot of the conversation choices could result in the death of a character over another in some cases.

It shows this was made by some of the oldschool Bioware guys who have since left that company.  The story and characters are all very interesting and I've only scratched the surface of the game.

The artwork and music stand out in this game more than any other I've played.  The art is only 2d but it's some of the most beautiful 2d artwork I've seen.  The music is perfect and fits the art with a very viking feeling to it.  The incombat animation is very smooth and looks great.

The gameplay reminds me of old FF and Suikoden games where you have many different heroes with different job classes.  There are as far as I can tell about 17 different job classes each with it's own special abilities.  Every character you get can be ranked up, have an item equiped etc.

If you are a turn based strategy, with a bit of RPG fan I highly highly recommend picking this game up.

Final Note:  This game has an auto save feature, which means not being able to save the game at every decision, making them far more important in the longrun.  Save Scummers beware, this is not the game for you.

reviewText:
Where do I start with this game. Well...it's amazing.
The art and animation are beautiful, story is book worthy, and this is one of the rare games I've played where choices actually matter. I think of this as part Fire Emblem and part Oregon Trail. Fighting is turn based and requires a good deal of strategy as when to take off enemy armor or go straight for their health as well when to use your characters abilities. In the overworld you need to make sure you have enough supplies to get you from city to city and along the way events will happen from thieves stealing supplies to possible permanent character death. The same points you use to buy supplies are used to upgrade you heroes. Do you use the points to make your fighters better or do you buy supplies so that you can get to the next city? I had moments while playing where I felt acutal despair as I watched my supplies run dry hoping that maybe I could find some more supplies from an event and cursing myself for using to many points to upgrade units.

Did I mention the art? Oh I did...WELL IT'S FREAKING GREAT!
Though I only saw one animated cutscene in the game just watching your caravan walk across the plains and seeing beautiful mountains at your back. The God Stones with their elaborate designs that also give you a little insight to the lore of the world. The in-fight animations are also very good and I think there's something really cool about the way the magic looks in the game.

I think this game was worth shelling out $25 but hey that's just me. With all of the choices you can make in the game I'm very willing to do a second playthrough on a harder difficulty.

reviewText:
I'd like to preface this review with some advice for playing it: In combat, weaken your enemies to about 1-3 health before starting to kill them, because the more enemies you kill, the more turns their surviving comrades get. People not getting this and getting beaten constantly is the number one source of criticism I see - people don't like it the combat because they don't understand this. To be fair to these people, the game never explains this, you have to learn it on your own. If you learn to use this approach early you'll get a lot more out of the game.

The way this game presents choices is a breath of a fresh air. To contrast with BioWare, where the major choices are all set pieces in Banner Saga they're presented much more organically. I've yet to beat the game, but already the story feels very personal based on my choices, compare this with other RPGs, where you often don't see the outcome of your decisions until the end.

*Possible Spoilers Below*

Something that's very interesting is the use of two protagonists. They manage to make playing as each caravan feel very different, in a good way. In one it's all about war and diplomacy, in the other it's all about desperation and survival. The different feel of playing as each is much appreciated.

*End Possible Spoilers*

The combat is incredibly satisfying. Normally, I prefer real time with pause combat, but Banner Saga's system is great. It's very tactical without feeling overwhelming.

The music and the art are just phenomenal. I can't do them justice here.

The world building is also great. It manages to draw effectively on Norse mythology and culture without feeling derivative. There's lots of familar imagery and themes but they're presented in a very fresh way. I'm playing the game as much to find out what happened in the world's past as I am to find out where the story goes. The setting is one of the game's biggest triumphs.

EDIT: Having now finished the game I'd like to add some more thoughs. The game as a whole is fantastic. I can't wait for the next episode - I want to see how my choices will affect the rest of the story. More than that, after the events of this episode I'm very excited to see how certain characters develop.

The character writing is very, very strong. I was surprised just how attached I became to some members of my party. There are some truly memorable personalities in this game.

The major set pieces of game are also fantastic. There are a couple of situations that you face that spread over multiple in game days, where you will be forced to make a lot of hard choices in rapid succession that are truly epic. I can't say any more than that as I couldn't imagine a greater disservice than spoiling in any fashion the two events I have in mind.

EDIT2: I'd like to add, if you liked The Walking Dead you'll enjoy Banner Saga. The characterisation of the protagonist and approach to choices are very similar and the stories even have some similar themes.

reviewText: The most remarkable aspect of this game is presentation. From the soundtrack to the art direction to the interface, everything is immaculate and elegant. Nothing feels rough around the edges or half-finished as far as those elements go. The gameplay is unique- a combination of choose-your-own-adventure style frequent decision-making, an Oregan Trail-like survival and travel element that involves some resource management, and the battle system itself which involves tactical strategy and some interesting components like individual health and defense bars to attack, and the Varl race of characters who take up a lot of unit space in battle but have high attack power. There are so many characters to choose from during battle- as many as 20 are encountered by game's end and even character usage involves some decision-making as characters only level up by not only actively participating, but getting in a number of kills.\n\nNow for some of the downsides- though there are such a plethora of options and routes to go on, nearly all lead toward the same end and plot points seem black and white in nature- you either picked the right" answer leading to hidden items or a surplus in resources

recommended: and the initially interesting tactics-driven combat is actually quite simplified compared to other strategy RPGs. Aspects such as equipment management involve collecting numerous accessories and each character can hold just one. Character classes and stat allocation is similarly straightforward. The Banner Saga is a phenomenal game - the perfect mix of Fire Emblem and Oregon Trail. I'm absolutely in love with the art style, music, and narrative.

The story progresses well, and is told magnificently. If you take the time to invest yourself in each character, you really start to feel their plight as the game moves forward.

Unfortunately, getting invested in the characters is difficult because of the large amount of text presented to the player in conversations. I know full voice-over for a game of this scope (and a small development team) is very expensive, but it's just a bit jarring to go from enthralling VO to text choices.

Overall, this is an excellent game that tells a great story in a beautiful setting. Worth playing.

reviewText:
A game that truly is a work of art from a developer that is just getting started.

Some things that really stand out
- the pace is slower, more thoughful and deliberate than other strategy games. Progression happens at a slow, steady march. Battles are fought with fewer units, and higher stakes.
- The map is extremely tolkien-esque, and packed with exquisite lore. This is a detailed, reactive world that you can get lost in. The developers understand that the more you know about a setting, the more emotionally invested you'll be.
- It's a joy to retrain your strategy instincts for this game. The mechanics are innovative, unusual. Character stats such as strength, armor and willpower don't mean what strategy/RPG game veterans might assume they mean.
- The game is balanced very, very well. Persistently difficult, but fair, with a long smooth learning curve.

The feature of the game that is most obvious is the art. Almost every screen from the battles to the menus looks and feels like a high-resolution, blu-ray remastering of a rotoscoped 80's animated film. What strikes me, though, is how well the art, the writing, and the game are unified in their artistic vision. This really is a masterpiece, and I will be waiting with baited breath for the next two entries in this trilogy.

reviewText:
Be aware that you are going to play this game for about 8 hours and absolutely love it, and then you'll be left dumbfounded by the direction it suddenly takes.

As I said, you'll love it; that is if you like the idea of a role-playing turn-based strategy game in which almost every character has their own unique abilities, and thus worth to a battle. Characters level up like in typical RPGs and you can equip them with stat-enhancing gear (only one though, and the highest level is 5). You'll quickly decide your front 6 and rarely deviate from it.

You will also learn that this game outright hates you, dealing you pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cards when you are called upon to make a decision. Not always ♥♥♥♥♥♥, however - some lead almost nowhere. But this where the story is primarily told, and because of these infrequent horrible decisions, and the occasional story-affecting choices, the saga feels like it's yours. I'm quite confident that someone out there has done precisely the same things as I did in this game, but, whilst I was playing it, it didn't feel that way.

The art style is pretty. Think 50's-80's Disney style stationary art with basic movements programmed in for battles, but with the minimal, yet highly appreciated, foreground and background falling snow to give it an easy 3D effect. Nice all around.

My only beef with this game is it's story, particularly the ending. It just ends to soon to put it plainly. Any self-respecting storywriter (who knows or does not know that they may be writing a trilogy) would not have ended it in this way. So many great and interesting angles are left unexplored and hardly explained! The Gods are dead (not much of a spoiler as it's right at the beginning of the game) and yet no explanation is offered. The sun has stopped moving (again, beginning) and no explanation is offered. The (apparent) main boss is introduced 2/3 of the way through without any previous hinting of how significant he's going to be. Why? Because his significance is paired with his existence. Very poor. And it's not even like he's a good main boss: there is a literal earth-shatterer that would have made for a killer main boss!

The storywriters need firing for this one. Actually, just fire the ones who argued that it should end in this way because they need to go back to junior school. I don't care if a trilogy had been in the plan the whole time, a good story does not introduce a key aspect of the storyline and then just do nothing with it.

I do recommend this though. It's a great game. The tone is excellent and it really feels like your saga. When you finish in a day (if your dedicated enough) you'll see what I mean by just how ♥♥♥♥ing disgraceful the ending is.

reviewText: An interesting and action-packed story, dialogue options which determine multiple possible fates, turn-based combat, and superb artistic direction make this a 'must have' RPG. True, 'upgrade' options can be narrow (max ranks of 5 levels) and the gameplay challenging, but difficulty can be moderated, and the limitations in skill-improving actually make this a more sensible game of strategy than a random hack-and-slash. Caravan management uses an economy of ‘renown’ (gained in battles) rather than coin to purchase supplies, upgrade characters, and buy items. This is a single-player game with no co-op or multiplayer options, but there is a ranked match version available for those who wish to purchase their way into games (Banner Sage: Factions). For $25 US you can expect to play the game through at least a few times and get your 'money's worth', but I would more fully recommend purchase of this game for $20 or less. 8.5/10 Gunjhars, with points being lost only for a lack of length and depth of world (fingers-crossed for an open-world version!) :D><

reviewText:
This game is immaculate, from the artwork and gameplay, to the way you manage supplies and your clans happiness during travels.  Every decision you make in the game is important and a lot of the conversation choices could result in the death of a character over another in some cases.

It shows this was made by some of the oldschool Bioware guys who have since left that company.  The story and characters are all very interesting and I've only scratched the surface of the game.

The artwork and music stand out in this game more than any other I've played.  The art is only 2d but it's some of the most beautiful 2d artwork I've seen.  The music is perfect and fits the art with a very viking feeling to it.  The incombat animation is very smooth and looks great.

The gameplay reminds me of old FF and Suikoden games where you have many different heroes with different job classes.  There are as far as I can tell about 17 different job classes each with it's own special abilities.  Every character you get can be ranked up, have an item equiped etc.

If you are a turn based strategy, with a bit of RPG fan I highly highly recommend picking this game up.

Final Note:  This game has an auto save feature, which means not being able to save the game at every decision, making them far more important in the longrun.  Save Scummers beware, this is not the game for you.

reviewText:
A game that truly is a work of art from a developer that is just getting started.

Some things that really stand out
- the pace is slower, more thoughful and deliberate than other strategy games. Progression happens at a slow, steady march. Battles are fought with fewer units, and higher stakes.
- The map is extremely tolkien-esque, and packed with exquisite lore. This is a detailed, reactive world that you can get lost in. The developers understand that the more you know about a setting, the more emotionally invested you'll be.
- It's a joy to retrain your strategy instincts for this game. The mechanics are innovative, unusual. Character stats such as strength, armor and willpower don't mean what strategy/RPG game veterans might assume they mean.
- The game is balanced very, very well. Persistently difficult, but fair, with a long smooth learning curve.

The feature of the game that is most obvious is the art. Almost every screen from the battles to the menus looks and feels like a high-resolution, blu-ray remastering of a rotoscoped 80's animated film. What strikes me, though, is how well the art, the writing, and the game are unified in their artistic vision. This really is a masterpiece, and I will be waiting with baited breath for the next two entries in this trilogy.

It is most likely something formed from my biased and practically purist views of SRPG's.



So first, the things I love ^_^

1-The Art
Cant say enough about this, its phenomenal and its like being in an interactive Disney game of brutality and brings me back to the SegaCD days and old PC of point and click adventure/exploring days. I could easily say; play this game to just be immensed inside this beautiful game.

2-The Music
It's very well composed and suited for everything thats going on in this story and era its cast in. I'm a musician/composer myself and cant help but appreciate it from that sense, but I would imagine most people who arent into music would only be pulled into the feelings of this game easier similar to a Hollywood movie.

3-SRPG Elements
Well..... I love this aspect of the game and its 90% of the reason I bought this game. I've played every SRPG I can get my hands on from Fire Emblem series and Final Fantasy Tactics to the overly diluted systems of Ogre Tactics and Disgaea. While I prefer a system that is well thought out with its boundaries and expansions within its systems, I do sometimes prefer a bit more of openness in the system such as Disgaea, but my mind tends to grow bored with endless options as everything becomes bland quicker than key roles that tend to shine within a system with some boundaries.

Back to this game though, its set up a bit differently. The classes are chosen ahead of time, if you can even call them classes, more like roles from the characters backgrounds. Archers,Bruisers,Tanks,Lancers,etc are some things you can expect to see early game. All with their own special moves and ranges on the map as well as movement across the map.

4-The Story Telling
Its great and very reminiscent of a great game that allows you to feel as if you have some control of the outlook of the characters,story,and ending. Games that come to mind are those of the Bethesda Series of Fallout and Elder Scrolls. Killing of key characters, ignoring causes for better or worse, choosing to help yourself or others, choosing sides/factions, and moving your Army" around the map to different encounters...well its all here. While I love this open book approach and multiple answer dialogue options I can definitely feel the sting of any choice I make afterwards.

So onto ....the hated aspects.

1-SRPG Elements Constrainments
This game has control of your progression...very tightly. I'm only assuming the developers wanted control of how you progress and made this decision intentionally. Since I dont appreciate the restriction personally
date: I disagree with the direction almost entirely. I know building those mechanics would take a lot of hours to put in place and could have been a budget decision or they could have wanted this part to be light and not focused on heavily by the player. I just cant help but want to(ignoring the fact that i'm a veteran and have lots of things to compare this system to) considering you are fighting...well 75% of the time and you are always ALWAYS at a disadvantage. Not a single fight in this game are you evenly matched none the less above the enemy. So with no way inside their system to really cater to your playing style
recommended: I find myself getting irritated with the lack of in the system. Its presence is there
hoursPlayed:
but its faint.

2-No Saving
Everytime I make a decision that affects something important
voteText: I prefer to be secure in my decision. I'm aware...Life doesnt have a pause button and once things are said and actions are done

reviewText:
I'm lost at words to describe how much I thoroughly enjoyed The Banner Saga. This title has such a mesmorizing score and astonishing artwork. Let's not forget about the  characters. Combining all that with the impressively well done story leaves you with an immersion one would not expect from an adventure game.

You are the leader of your clansmen and during your adventure you encounter numerious trials and tribulations, many which will leave you questioning your morale compass. To name a few: Starving strangers, backstabbers, gluttony, schemers, gender equality, racism. How will you deal with them in each encounter? How will you deal with troublemakers in your caravan? I found this to be very much like The Walking Dead mixed with Oregon/Organ Trail in terms of the choices you are make!

The game eases you into the story and gameplay mechanics. The turn-based combat system is very easy to understand with a steep learning curve. Players who are familiar with tabletop, armor values, attack values, etc won't have as much trouble. The difficulty is in the risk factor. There are two values, Strength and Shield; Strength is for attack value and health while Shield is your armor value that reduces incoming Strength attacks. Despite how this all looks really simple, it's a lot more complicated. I had a very interesting time learning how to maximize the effectiveness of combat. There is also a limited resource called Will that you can exert your troops to more further or deal more damage. Do you weaken the enemy shield first before dealing a swift deathly blow or do you attack their strength and make them deal less damage in return?

I am a huge fan of the story and setting. I love Norse mytho and Banner Saga has numerous hints of it as inspiration. I'm also fond of many of the characters personalities and how well detailed they are. They have layers of complexion and every single one of them have their own goals/motives/opinions; strangers can become allies, allies can become enemies. However, looking back, I wasn't able to bond with most of the characters...strange.

I cannot applaud the developers enough. This here, The Banner Saga, is a work of art. I cannot sing enough praise.

reviewText: This game is essentially The Oregon Trail, but with a Nordic fantasy theme and a rudimentary turn-based combat system akin to Final Fantasy Tactics or X-Com (but with substantially less depth). Unfortunately, it is a very short while; most players will find themselves wanting more content after the final battle. Buy the game if it is on sale for less than $20 and I suspect you will feel rewarded by the purchase. In my opinion, the $25 price point is just a bit too high for the amount of gameplay you get.\n\nI sincerely hope that a sequel is in the works; one with a hundred hours of gameplay and a more robust combat system. reviewText:
This game is one of those ever increasingly rare games that prove video games can be more than just a few hours of entertainment, they can be interactive art. the art style is incredible and animations are pretty well done, and the decisions you make the whole way are gut wrenching and could either help save you, or cause you problems. Trust this person, or this person, and if you trust the wrong one, then you could get betrayed. Sacrifice your travelling companions for your combat party, or risk yourselves for the better good. It truly started making me start questioning every decision, and really makes you question yourself as a leader.

Rook, basically the main character (theres a bunch of little storylines in there, but you are mostly playing as Rook), was simply a hunter, seeking to live a safe quiet life while protecting his daughter, when suddenly you are attacked and the leader of your small village is killed, and suddenly, everyone looks to you as the new leader. Thrust into your sudden leadership role, you must make tough decisions, that only get tougher as you go from leading a mere couple of dozen people to leading over 300-400+, all while seeking to protect the group and your daughter, and seek salvation.

As for the combat, the strategy is a bit tough to get used to, but incredibly well done, and makes you start depending on your team, but that can go badly if you make a poor decision and get one of those main allies killed. Leveling up is well done, especially since your Renown" which you have to spend each time you level up and buy stuff like supplies and items

First thing you will notice about the banner saga is the art, rotoscoping isn't something that you see everyday let alone in a video game and the bannar saga excels at making each person, place or thing you encounter on your journey really come to life with beauty.
Speaking of journey the music in this game is composed by Austin Wintory who did the music for the game Journey. The entire game sounds fantastic from the heavy beating of drums to the triumphant bellow of horns the entire sounds epic from start to finish.
As I said before the game really feels like a great mix of turn based tactics and Oregon trail. Combat takes place on a grid and you and the enemy take turns bashing each other. With each character having different strengths and weaknesses and a simple yet deeping twist on how your units health works the game really makes you feel accomplished for each and ever battle you win. That is a good thing because honestly this like to give you a bad hand a lot.
The other half of the game is the traveling part, as you and your viking caravan cross mountians and icy wastes you must deal with a number of issues such as Do we have enough food?" "Can we trust these strangers we just met?" The game makes you choose and everything you do has an effect on the caravan as a whole. Letting some strangers join you might mean they steal a bunch of the food in the night and then suddenly you are in the middle of nowhere and people are starving to death right and left as you push forward. You must make tough choices often times sacrificing one resource or another while trying to keep the people and warriors you take on in good spirits.

In the end the Banner saga is a deep game with rich lore and a enduring characters and it's a adventure worth taking."

reviewText:
This game is immaculate, from the artwork and gameplay, to the way you manage supplies and your clans happiness during travels.  Every decision you make in the game is important and a lot of the conversation choices could result in the death of a character over another in some cases.

It shows this was made by some of the oldschool Bioware guys who have since left that company.  The story and characters are all very interesting and I've only scratched the surface of the game.

The artwork and music stand out in this game more than any other I've played.  The art is only 2d but it's some of the most beautiful 2d artwork I've seen.  The music is perfect and fits the art with a very viking feeling to it.  The incombat animation is very smooth and looks great.

The gameplay reminds me of old FF and Suikoden games where you have many different heroes with different job classes.  There are as far as I can tell about 17 different job classes each with it's own special abilities.  Every character you get can be ranked up, have an item equiped etc.

If you are a turn based strategy, with a bit of RPG fan I highly highly recommend picking this game up.

Final Note:  This game has an auto save feature, which means not being able to save the game at every decision, making them far more important in the longrun.  Save Scummers beware, this is not the game for you.

reviewText:
So this game....is great! I have many kind words to say about this and being a huge Final Fantasy Tactics(SRPG's for that matter) fan this was a real treat to see on Steam's front page one day. I have some things about the game I love and I have some things about the game...well that I actually hate. Yes, it has left that much distaste in my mouth haha but thats not to discourage you. It is most likely something formed from my biased and practically purist views of SRPG's.



So first, the things I love ^_^

1-The Art
Cant say enough about this, its phenomenal and its like being in an interactive Disney game of brutality and brings me back to the SegaCD days and old PC of point and click adventure/exploring days. I could easily say; play this game to just be immensed inside this beautiful game.

2-The Music
It's very well composed and suited for everything thats going on in this story and era its cast in. I'm a musician/composer myself and cant help but appreciate it from that sense, but I would imagine most people who arent into music would only be pulled into the feelings of this game easier similar to a Hollywood movie.

3-SRPG Elements
Well..... I love this aspect of the game and its 90% of the reason I bought this game. I've played every SRPG I can get my hands on from Fire Emblem series and Final Fantasy Tactics to the overly diluted systems of Ogre Tactics and Disgaea. While I prefer a system that is well thought out with its boundaries and expansions within its systems, I do sometimes prefer a bit more of openness in the system such as Disgaea, but my mind tends to grow bored with endless options as everything becomes bland quicker than key roles that tend to shine within a system with some boundaries.

Back to this game though, its set up a bit differently. The classes are chosen ahead of time, if you can even call them classes, more like roles from the characters backgrounds. Archers,Bruisers,Tanks,Lancers,etc are some things you can expect to see early game. All with their own special moves and ranges on the map as well as movement across the map.

4-The Story Telling
Its great and very reminiscent of a great game that allows you to feel as if you have some control of the outlook of the characters,story,and ending. Games that come to mind are those of the Bethesda Series of Fallout and Elder Scrolls. Killing of key characters, ignoring causes for better or worse, choosing to help yourself or others, choosing sides/factions, and moving your Army" around the map to different encounters...well its all here. While I love this open book approach and multiple answer dialogue options I can definitely feel the sting of any choice I make afterwards.

So onto ....the hated aspects.

1-SRPG Elements Constrainments
This game has control of your progression...very tightly. I'm only assuming the developers wanted control of how you progress and made this decision intentionally. Since I dont appreciate the restriction personally
date: I disagree with the direction almost entirely. I know building those mechanics would take a lot of hours to put in place and could have been a budget decision or they could have wanted this part to be light and not focused on heavily by the player. I just cant help but want to(ignoring the fact that i'm a veteran and have lots of things to compare this system to) considering you are fighting...well 75% of the time and you are always ALWAYS at a disadvantage. but its faint.

Everytime I make a decision that affects something important

reviewText:
Banner Saga is a study in videogames as a storytelling medium. The score, the sounds, the visual style, and the writing all work together beautifully to tell the story of a merciless world falling apart. It's tense and you're always on the verge of annihilation, and the music alone could tell you so. It's gritty, and the crunches of axes breaking armor and the grunts and moans of the injured make you feel it. People are fragile and the perpetual march is exhausting, and the heavy shambling motions of bodies shows you so.  As the leader, you constantly have to arbitrate the problems of your followers, keep them optimistic, keep them fed, and keep them alive while a continent of panicking and desperate people is being overrun.  Everything harmoniously comes together to weave an atmosphere where feelings of dread and anxiety are constant. Your choice isn't whether or not people die, it's who dies now so that fewer will die later.  In every artistic regard this game is an achievement.

Unfortunately it's not for everyone, though. Its roots are in the artistry, not the gameplay--people have some valid complaints about that. Only some. I didn't dislike the gameplay at all, but I was very wrapped up in every other part of the game.

Play it for the experience.

reviewText:
I'm lost at words to describe how much I thoroughly enjoyed The Banner Saga. This title has such a mesmorizing score and astonishing artwork. Let's not forget about the  characters. Combining all that with the impressively well done story leaves you with an immersion one would not expect from an adventure game.

You are the leader of your clansmen and during your adventure you encounter numerious trials and tribulations, many which will leave you questioning your morale compass. To name a few: Starving strangers, backstabbers, gluttony, schemers, gender equality, racism. How will you deal with them in each encounter? How will you deal with troublemakers in your caravan? I found this to be very much like The Walking Dead mixed with Oregon/Organ Trail in terms of the choices you are make!

The game eases you into the story and gameplay mechanics. The turn-based combat system is very easy to understand with a steep learning curve. Players who are familiar with tabletop, armor values, attack values, etc won't have as much trouble. The difficulty is in the risk factor. There are two values, Strength and Shield; Strength is for attack value and health while Shield is your armor value that reduces incoming Strength attacks. Despite how this all looks really simple, it's a lot more complicated. I had a very interesting time learning how to maximize the effectiveness of combat. There is also a limited resource called Will that you can exert your troops to more further or deal more damage. Do you weaken the enemy shield first before dealing a swift deathly blow or do you attack their strength and make them deal less damage in return?

I am a huge fan of the story and setting. I love Norse mytho and Banner Saga has numerous hints of it as inspiration. I'm also fond of many of the characters personalities and how well detailed they are. reviewText: The Banner Saga is an extraordinary game. Starting with the obvious, the landscapes and soundtrack are both breathtaking and plain epic. But what what really reeled me in, even more than the wonderful and immersive atmosphere, is the storyline. Twisted, and relying so very much on the player's choices. You often don't know where you're going, what to decide, whom you should trust or not, and must rely on your own judgement (often wrong !) and guts to advance. It is such a pleasure to feel like you're are actually choosing, or creating your own path rather than following the same patterns as always ; and it's not so often that a game really makes you think twice about a choice that will (maybe) haunt you until the end... The Banner Saga is really a refreshing creation, dark indeed, but beautiful nonetheless, and takes you in without mercy. I just finished it, and already want to discover all the other paths that lie ahead... I recommend it whole-heartedly !

reviewText:
TL;DR This is the game of the year for me, a work of art and a classic already in my mind.

The Banner Saga is a game I did not look forward to, but which has surprised me in on every level. The fights are hard without feeling unfair. Resource management is amazingly difficult. The story and dialogues are well written and captivating. The art is beautiful and the soundtrack is simply amazing. The choices one has to face are hard but interesting and seem like they will suck me right back in when I return to the game. The voice acting is so well done that I wish that all of the dialogues would be spoken. The sound design just blew my mind in parts of the game. I think there's really nothing to add that could make the game better, it's to the point.

This is one of the few games that have a soundtrack so well done that I've been listening to it since I own it. And it's one of the few games that has brought tears to my eyes. This is already a classic, due to it's superb design.

reviewText:
The Banner Saga is a post-apocalyptic Viking Age Oregon Trail with fights. If you're still reading instead of buying this game on that description alone, fine - let's get serious: The Banner Saga is a story-driven, turn-based strategy-RPG with incredible art and music that oozes atmosphere and sucks you right into its bleak yet beautiful world.

Basically the game tells the story of caravans of Nordic humans and horned giants called Varl struggling to survive after Ragnarok. The gods are dead. The sun has stopped moving in the sky. A great darkness is descending from the North, bringing with it an unstoppable host of mysterious stone creatures called Dredge. The game looks like a Disney animated feature (one of the good ones), but the story has more in common with Game of Thrones than Pocahontas, filled with old blood feuds, betrayal, and grey morality. The point of view switches back and forth a few times at first, getting the player acquainted with the many different characters. Players who aren't paying close attention may find themselves confused, especially in the dialogue scenes where it's not always made abundantly clear who is speaking.

The art in this game is gorgeous - just look at the screenshots. Unfortunately the only fully animated and voiced sequence comes at the very beginning, and all of the following dialogue scenes are silent and only minimally animated (blinking eyes, blowing hair, etc.). A bit more animation in the conversations - changing facial expressions to fit what is being said, for instance - would not have been amiss. But even so, everything looks fantastic, including the character animations in combat.

reviewText:
This game is immaculate, from the artwork and gameplay, to the way you manage supplies and your clans happiness during travels.  Every decision you make in the game is important and a lot of the conversation choices could result in the death of a character over another in some cases.

It shows this was made by some of the oldschool Bioware guys who have since left that company.  The story and characters are all very interesting and I've only scratched the surface of the game.

The artwork and music stand out in this game more than any other I've played.  The art is only 2d but it's some of the most beautiful 2d artwork I've seen.  The music is perfect and fits the art with a very viking feeling to it.  The incombat animation is very smooth and looks great.

The gameplay reminds me of old FF and Suikoden games where you have many different heroes with different job classes.  There are as far as I can tell about 17 different job classes each with it's own special abilities.  Every character you get can be ranked up, have an item equiped etc.

If you are a turn based strategy, with a bit of RPG fan I highly highly recommend picking this game up.

Final Note:  This game has an auto save feature, which means not being able to save the game at every decision, making them far more important in the longrun.  Save Scummers beware, this is not the game for you.

reviewText:
Highly recommended. Great strategy game with an intriguing story. Been playing this with my non-gamer wife watching and helping me make the story decisions while I handle combat for the most part. 18 hours in  she's  telling me how to spec out the party and what to do each turn. Easy to get into but suprisingly deep while offering a lot of ambiguous choices with unforseeable consequences which can dramatically impact both the story and mechanical character progression/combat.

Its not a game you can ace. It's a game where you have to live with the consequences of your choices, whatever they may be, and there isn't always a clear right or wrong decision for every situation.

Did I mention it's gorgeous and the music is spectacular? Worth noting that it works well as a mouse-only game, making it a turn based strategy game that plays well on the TV from the couch. Most enjoyable turn-based strategy RPG I've played in a long time.

reviewText:
TLDR: Banner Saga left me with an intense hunger for more, which is so much worse as the game is so awesome!

If you like the Fire Emblem series, consider playing this game. It has some interesting takes on the tactical RPG genre, an awesome art style with beutiful scenery and rich characters. I found the story interesting and was especially impressed by the hardship and difficult choices of a refugee story arc.

I was, however, also a little frustrated. The skill caps of your heros are very low, and I feel the leveling/customization choices  are quite limited. At least you get a lot of heros to try out but you don't get enough time and resources to explore them all very well. I also did not like that the narrative unnecessarily imposes that you play a certain character. Especially in a part, where Alette, a relatable girl, could easily be the main character you are forced into the role of Rook, her father, and have to decide her fate with some patronizing choices. And then the story ends very abruptly.

reviewText:
Banner Saga is a study in videogames as a storytelling medium. The score, the sounds, the visual style, and the writing all work together beautifully to tell the story of a merciless world falling apart. It's tense and you're always on the verge of annihilation, and the music alone could tell you so. It's gritty, and the crunches of axes breaking armor and the grunts and moans of the injured make you feel it. People are fragile and the perpetual march is exhausting, and the heavy shambling motions of bodies shows you so.  As the leader, you constantly have to arbitrate the problems of your followers, keep them optimistic, keep them fed, and keep them alive while a continent of panicking and desperate people is being overrun.  Everything harmoniously comes together to weave an atmosphere where feelings of dread and anxiety are constant. Your choice isn't whether or not people die, it's who dies now so that fewer will die later.  In every artistic regard this game is an achievement.

Unfortunately it's not for everyone, though. Its roots are in the artistry, not the gameplay--people have some valid complaints about that. Only some. I didn't dislike the gameplay at all, but I was very wrapped up in every other part of the game.

Play it for the experience.

reviewText: There is so much that made me want to love this game. However, the strength system is horribly unbalanced heavily favoring units like warhawks while units like archers have little recourse once an enemy is upon them. Couple this with the fact that units you invest in can very abruptly die via text menu decisions and you've laid the path for a brutally unlikable experience. I'm also not terribly fond of the inability to move after issuing a command nor am I fond of chain battles when there isn't any sort of healing. Not being able to move through my own units was also not well thought out.\n\nWhile you can advance units by spending Renown on them it quickly becomes expensive and the stat points you're allowed to allocate are sparse at best. Couple this with the fact that a unit can leave or die at any time and I have to wonder why anyone would bother. As well, the save system is janky as hell. Want to save and come back whenever you like? Too bad - you're back at the start of the chapter. I guess now you can maybe stop that party member from abruptly dying. Sloppy decisions. It's a shame - the game is beautiful.

reviewText:
Oregon Trail meets Final Fantasy Tactics!

-Overview-
Seriously this game is very fun and has a way of drawing you in. The neatest part that will also be the most frustrating is that you cannot create save slots. So if you are at a juncture and someone dies, they stay dead in your game. Don't worry, characters that fall in combat will only be injured for an amount of days equal to how badly they got gibbed in battle (at least on normal difficulty). But sometimes people will die as a result of your actions and then they are just dead. The story is well done with some twists along the way. The setting is the real powerhouse though - it's the end of the world and you are trying to eke out some survival. It's reminiscent to zombie apocalypse games because the dredge you fight seem rather mindless. What saves it is the nordic fantasy theme and the varls. The varls are apparently a cross between human and ox, but they live for hundreds of years and are basically giants. Also they cannot reproduce anymore so the amount left is finite.

-Gameplay-
There are 2 main screens in the game, the traveling screen which tracks how many people, varls, and supplies you have as you trek across the landscape and the grid battle view where you fight tactical combats. Overall both of these systems work very well. I was frustrated at first by how frequently my archers and other squishies died. Now I treat them like fragile objects and play very carefully with them. It isn't worth it to run halfway across the map for a kill only to get swarmed and killed. Send the tanks in first, create a wall, then pepper them with your long-range units. Instead of getting gold and experience you acquire Renown which functions as a currency for everything in the game. Want to buy an item? Spend renown. Want to buy food supplies? Spend renown. Want to level up your army? Spend renown. Obviously you don't get enough to do it all, so you balance losing women and children with wanting to have a stronger army to fight through and save the rest of the caravan. Lots of little decisions come back later in the game too, which shows you that your choices do matter. Overall it's very fun and addicting, with a One More Turn Style" gameplay.

-Story-
It just throws you into this lord of the rings inspired setting

reviewText: One part tactical combat, one part RPG, one part Oregon Trail. The game has an intense storyline that makes the player really feel the urgency of the characters. Part of this is due to the way renown
date:
or the game's version of XP works. Renown can either be spent leveling up your characters OR on supplies to keep people alive -- and there's never quite enough renown to go around. The use of scarce resources works really well into the storyline and even more into the player's decisions of what to do. I'm not really much of a tactical combat fan so I was surprised by how much I really enjoyed the game.

The best part, however, are the really amazing visuals (outside of cutscenes). I plan on playing through the game a second time just so I can screencap some of the scenes. And even better than the graphics? The music.

Really the only thing I could complain about is that the end of the game doesn't really feel like an ending. It's more of a resolution to the current situation than a resolution to the entire storyline. Of course, this may mean a sequel in the future!

reviewText:
The Banner Saga is probably one of the best games I've played in recent memory; the cast is made of characters who are dynamic enough to be difficult to explain in one sentence or trope, the aesthetics are a marvel for the eyes, and Austin Wintory's score for the game compliments the desolate nature of the game quite well.
It's also quite nice to see a strategy game where--for the most part--turns go back and forth, almost like a game of chess, instead of moving your entire army and dominating in one turn. Many of the choices presented to you throughout the story are legitimately hard decisions to make, and the possibility of losing party members or forsaking rewards makes you think about your options, and makes each run of this game a little more unique.
I do have my gripes with it though: some of the classes don't feel too unique from each other, special attacks aside, and for the most part, the story doesn't really branch out much. Your decisions do indeed affect immediate events, but you're still locked on the story progression the game wants you to take.
Don't let that be a turn-off, however. I've poured nearly 12 hours into this game, and I've enjoyed each one of them.

FINAL GRADE: A-
Highly recommended, but there's considerable room for improvement.

reviewText:
With so many games resembling a good meal, like a steak with a side of mashed potatoes and some juicy sauce, I've been fed up with AAA titles recently. The Banner Saga is like an exquisite dessert. The portion is small, yes, but the flavour is so unique that you would definetly want more.

Food metaphores aside, I recommend this game highly. The combat mechanics are great, the visuals are awe-inspiring, yada-yada-yada. The thing that got to me most, is the atmosphere of complete desperation. The world is ending, and there's nothing you can do about it. No heroes to battle the darkness and win, no magical swords to end the enemy horde's approach. Every victory is temporary, you run, losing people and land. You learn to appreciate small things, like getting a bunch of supplies from a village. HELL YES, my caravan will not starve for a whole day! This tension gets kind of exhausting after a while, but the game is short enough for this not to be a problem.

If you like RPG's, tactical combat, good storytelling, all things viking and norse - this game is your kind of savoury meal.

reviewText:
the Banner Saga does a good job capturing a nordic spirit: it's beautiful but harsh, and really soul-crushing at times.

besides having to manage your caravan so everybody doesn't die, the game puts a somewhat different spin on the usual turn-based combat mechanics: armor has to be worn down before decent hp damage can be done, and hitpoints double as the attack strength characteristic. additionally, willpower lets characters push themselves further and execute special attacks depending on their class. it works well but can be a litte unforgiving of mistakes, tactics are important.

the decisions you have to make outside of combat are harsh as well - things that look like they worked out fine at first can turn around to bite you in the ♥♥♥ later, and that includes character progression. the return of those points you spent on your hero isn't that great if they're dead or gone... you might start second-guessing a lot, but you won't really be safer for it. which makes for a rather captivating if depressing story.

I really liked the art, and the soundtrack adds nicely to the atmosphere, becoming more prominent when it is fitting.
the overarching story is interesting and makes numerous references to a rich lore - too bad that answers aren't something you'll get. this is part of what makes the rather abrupt ending somewhat unsatisfying, sadly one of the Banner Saga's weaker points. still...

it's not a perfect game, but I'd definitely recommend it!

reviewText:
The Banner Saga is probably one of the best games I've played in recent memory; the cast is made of characters who are dynamic enough to be difficult to explain in one sentence or trope, the aesthetics are a marvel for the eyes, and Austin Wintory's score for the game compliments the desolate nature of the game quite well.
It's also quite nice to see a strategy game where--for the most part--turns go back and forth, almost like a game of chess, instead of moving your entire army and dominating in one turn. Many of the choices presented to you throughout the story are legitimately hard decisions to make, and the possibility of losing party members or forsaking rewards makes you think about your options, and makes each run of this game a little more unique.
I do have my gripes with it though: some of the classes don't feel too unique from each other, special attacks aside, and for the most part, the story doesn't really branch out much. Your decisions do indeed affect immediate events, but you're still locked on the story progression the game wants you to take.
Don't let that be a turn-off, however. I've poured nearly 12 hours into this game, and I've enjoyed each one of them.

FINAL GRADE: A-
Highly recommended, but there's considerable room for improvement.

reviewText:
An emotive and beautiful journey through Viking legend, this game stands out both as an excellent strategy game, and as a true work of art.

The hand-drawn artwork is sublime, and highly original in today's 3D obsessed world. The cast of dozens are beautifully rendered and animated, and set in the backdrop of a beautiful world in turmoil. The gods are dead, the sun has stopped, and something evil is coming.

The story sucks you in, and challenges you with difficult moral and tactical choices throughout the game. Not only must you prevail on the battlefield, you must protect, feed and care for a growing caravan of refugees fleeing the evil on your tail. As your caravan traverses the beautiful windswept landscape you watch the narrative unfold, with each choice impacting on your fighting capability, morale, and dwindling food supplies.

There are no easy choices. I am writing this review after my second playthrough, and can better appreciate this. The story is essentially linear, but seemingly innocuous choices could end the life of your favourite hero, or leave you with a knife in your back. Most games give hints to possible outcomes; The Banner Saga teaches you that life is arbitrary, cruel, and that you can't save everyone. The only consolation is perhaps that no matter how bad things get, none of your choices can (I think) make the game unwinnable - but you will live with the burden of knowing that had you chosen more wisely, perhaps more lives could have been saved.

Combat is turn based, and, until the get the hang of it, pretty brutal. In another nod to realism, health and attack strength is linked - an injury means your hero can't hit as hard. As your team is weakened, each successive wound compounds upon the last, spiralling you closer to defeat. Battles can be nail-biting affairs, but the tension this mechanic creates is delicious, and makes prevailing all the sweeter. My only criticism is that there were too many monotonous battles mid-game, but perservere, and your skills and your heroes will be honed for your ultimate confrontation in the last chapter.

reviewText:
An emotive and beautiful journey through Viking legend, this game stands out both as an excellent strategy game, and as a true work of art.

The hand-drawn artwork is sublime, and highly original in today's 3D obsessed world. The cast of dozens are beautifully rendered and animated, and set in the backdrop of a beautiful world in turmoil. The gods are dead, the sun has stopped, and something evil is coming.

The story sucks you in, and challenges you with difficult moral and tactical choices throughout the game. Not only must you prevail on the battlefield, you must protect, feed and care for a growing caravan of refugees fleeing the evil on your tail. As your caravan traverses the beautiful windswept landscape you watch the narrative unfold, with each choice impacting on your fighting capability, morale, and dwindling food supplies.

There are no easy choices. I am writing this review after my second playthrough, and can better appreciate this. The story is essentially linear, but seemingly innocuous choices could end the life of your favourite hero, or leave you with a knife in your back. Most games give hints to possible outcomes; The Banner Saga teaches you that life is arbitrary, cruel, and that you can't save everyone. The only consolation is perhaps that no matter how bad things get, none of your choices can (I think) make the game unwinnable - but you will live with the burden of knowing that had you chosen more wisely, perhaps more lives could have been saved.

Combat is turn based, and, until the get the hang of it, pretty brutal. In another nod to realism, health and attack strength is linked - an injury means your hero can't hit as hard. As your team is weakened, each successive wound compounds upon the last, spiralling you closer to defeat. Battles can be nail-biting affairs, but the tension this mechanic creates is delicious, and makes prevailing all the sweeter. My only criticism is that there were too many monotonous battles mid-game, but perservere, and your skills and your heroes will be honed for your ultimate confrontation in the last chapter.

Despite its minor flaws, I thoroughly enjoyed this game; twice. Each path taken was another surprise, and deepened my appreciation of the thought, effort and love that went into this accomplished KickStarter project. A fantastic and memorable experience, and a big thumbs up from me.

reviewText:
The gods are dead, the sun stood still and the world, inhabited by humans and giants, is on the brink of destruction - these are the first words of the Banner Saga introduction. The game was created by Stoic Studio, was founded by people from the famous BioWare Studio, gave the world such great role-playing games like Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic, Mass Effect and Dragon Age.

World of Banner Saga is gloomy, harsh and designed to the last detail. Inspired by Scandinavian mythology and stories about the vikings. Before the player unfolds a fascinating story, will be given the opportunity to observe developments from the point of view of several different main characters. Hunter Rook with his daughter Alette are saved from their village, which was attacked by dredges, dark warriors, whose armies are threatening to destroy all life in this world. Giant Hakon leads an army together with the human prince Ludin to help Grofheim, besieged the capital of the Kingdom.

Banner Saga is role-playing game (RPG) with turn-based battles. During the 8-9 hours of the game player will have to make the hard decisions and none of the proposed options will be not definitely good, you always have to face the consequences of your decisions. The player will lead to the final goal not only the main characters, the number of which is constantly changing - someone will come, someone will leave, and someone will die. Also player will be responsible for the people, who walking in the caravan with him: refugees fleeing from dredges, who destroyed their home.

Especially I want to tell about plot and dialogues. All dialogues in the game are presented in the form of large amounts of text. The text is extremely high quality, it is like you situate in an interactive book where you decide what and how will happen next.

Music plays a huge role in creating the atmosphere of the approaching end of the world. Scandinavian themes  plays on the background of colorful snowy scenery and it is just incredible. Under calm music caravan covers the distance from one village to another, under the anxious music soldiers and giants go to the last battle against horrible dredges to protect their families. Under such musical compositions I would like to sincerely empathize with the characters.

For this game I would waste my free day, wrapped in a blanket with a cup of warm cocoa. The music and visual style of  Banner Saga make the game like complete artwork, which I will replay several times, to get new impressions.

10 brave vikings out of 10. Excellent.

reviewText:
It's Oregon Trail + Final Fantasy Tactics lite. The combat seems pretty simple on the surface, but they way they use Armor and Strength is neat. A unit's Strength is effectively their HP, and the damage a unit can do is Strength - Armor.  If a unit's Strength < opponent's Armor, they have a (Armor - Strength)*10% chance to miss completely.  If you ignore armor and go for strength attacks, you run the risk of missing with your weaker characters, but if you only focus on armor, they can do more damage to you on their turn.

Between fights, you're on an oregon trail style adventure after the invasion of your village by Dredge, a race of heavily armored people from the north. They're the main antagonists of the game, forcing the main characters to flee from city to city looking for refuge. The number of supplies you have determine how many days you can travel before your clansmen and warriors begin to die. In addition, the longer you travel, the worse your clan's morale gets, meaning you have to balance supplies with camping and resting. Various dialog and story events play a part in the number of clansmen you lose or gain if they decide to join your caravan.

The story mainly revolves around a hunter named Rook, who falls into the leadership role in a caravan of refugees. You and the other characters are attempting to find refuge between two separate apocalyptic events and a horde of invading warriors. Similar to Game of Thrones, the story is barely ever not dark, but it fits the tone of the world. You're not on a quest to save the planet, you're just trying to get your people to safety.

Only downside is that it lacks closure on some of the bigger story elements. Looking forward to the sequel.
